Problem:
Consider the differential equation \\( \\frac{dx}{dt} = Ax \\) governing a system, where \\( A \\) is a constant matrix. A Fourier transform \\( F(s) = \\int_0^\\infty e^{-st}x(t) dt \\) is applied to transform the function over time.

If \\( x(t) \\) evolves under the rule \\( \\frac{dx}{dt} = Ax \\) from t = 0 to t = T without any intervention, will the Fourier transform at the end, \\( F(T) \\), be similar to applying the Fourier transform at any intermediate time t and continuing from there?
Explanation: The Fourier transform incorporates all the history of \\( x(t) \\) from 0 to infinity, scaling each moment by \\( e^{-st} \\). Transforming at an intermediate time t and continuing means losing all contributions from earlier times, thus affecting the result of \\( F(T) \\).
